channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for VT
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for VT

item.title: Report X-2025020031
item.description:
Report X-2025020031

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-05T03:26:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-31
  • City: SOUTH BURLINGTON
  • State: VT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package was found on a van line with an exterior stain visible on the cardboard packaging. Upon inspection by QA, it was found that the stain was caused by the contents leaking internally. Three of the four plastic bottles contained in the outer box had loose caps, which allowed their contents to partially spill during transport. There was no sign of damage by dropping, crushing or other mishandling which might have caused the caps to loosen. The leak was confined to the origin package - no other packages were affected, and QA was able to remove the package from the sort before any employees came in contact with the leaking substance.

item.title: Report E-2025010375
item.description:
Report E-2025010375

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-31T00:56:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-28
  • City: WILLISTON
  • State: VT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: A. DUIE PYLE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: While unloading freight from trailer material handler found 2 bags on a pallet of 25 bags slightly leaking. The 2 bags that were leaking were overhanging the pallet and must have been hit by other freight or something that tore them open and consequently contributed to the unintentional release. Spilled material was swept up and placed into a recovery container and the two bags were repaired and placed into a recovery container and sent to ultimate consignee.

  • Description: DRIVER DICOVERED LEAK WHEN CUSTOMER NOTICED IT WAS LEAKING AND REFUSED DELIVERY. DRIVER NOTIFIED SUPERVISOR AND HE RESPONDED TO RETRIEVE PACKAGE FROM CUSTOMER DOCK. DAMAGE WAS COMING FROM A LOOSE CAP
